Claim: Traditional bullfighting - the practice of fighting with bulls that includes physically injuring them - should be banned.
Bullfighting, as a male-dominated sport, reinforces harmful gender stereotypes.
Historically, women have been left out of bullfighting as active subjects. Participation in the practice has been forbidden for women in different times throughout Spanish history.
For centuries, women could only be eye-candy for male spectators or the bullfighter's suffering mother or wife (p. 36).

In the first volumes of the Cossío (the most important bullfighting encyclopaedia, which continues to be updated and revised) out of 4,125 pages, only 11 are dedicated to women and only under comical shows, ignoring pioneers like Conchita Cintrón or Juanita Cruz (p. 3-4).
There are currently no discussions to forbid women's participation in bullfighting.

The town of Astorga promoted a bullfighting festivity in honour of “the Spanish Women”, in which women (and children under 8) could enter for free, as long as they went with someone holding a ticket (a man). This is an initiative that equates women to children and uses them as a tactic to increase attendance.

When the Indian Supreme Court banned jallikattu (bullfighting) in Tamil Nadu, animal rights activists like Tamil actress Trisha faced misogynist attacks by fans. The male actors who took a similar stand were not targeted by the protesters.
This may have nothing to do with bullfighting specifically, as high-profile women who take public stances on political issues generally receive substantial amounts of abuse and threats.

The issues where women face mysoginist attacks are generally those where there is a masculinity ethos, i.e., those where qualities such as strenght are valued over ethical qualities like kindness and compassion. Therefore, even though it is very common to see this kind of attack happening in many issues, bullfighting seems to be prone to this kind of attack.
Bullfighting could easily become more inclusive for women in the future. The current situation is no reason to outright ban the sport.
If female bullfighters are successful, as some were in the 1990s, there will be pressure to change the traditional male-dominated narratives of bullfighting.

Female bullfighters - such as Beatriz Romero, Joaquina Ariza or Cristina Sánchez - have proved their mastery in the arena, yet they have endured sexism in the form of fewer bookings, less payment, and less recognition, among other issues.

For example, in Portugal, there are two parts of the bullfight, one where the bullfighter on a horse puts some kind of sticks in the bull, the other where the 'forcados' stop the bull by immobilizing him. In the first category there are many famous female bullfighters and almost always is there a woman fighting, in the second, there is less representation, but there are female groups of 'forcados'.
An activity being primarily done by men does not necessarily mean that it reinforces gender stereotypes.
There are no separate categories for men and women in bullfighting.
This might well be a result of the absence of women in the sport. Where there are no women, there is no need for a separate category of women's bullfighting.

If there are no women in the sport, the cause of that should be questioned. It may be driven by hostility of the sport towards women, or a lack of opportunities being provided to women to participate.
Other male-dominated sports, such as American football, are not prohibited.
In the same vein, some disciplines are widely accepted to include only women, for example Synchronised Swimming and Rhythmic Gymnastics at the Olympics.
There is an increasing movement to establish male leagues in each of these sports.

Indeed, in the case of sychronised swimming, men were equally involved at its onset, before the genders were separated for modesty reasons, and lack of participant interest in the male league led to its collapse.
American football has recently seen the first female player on an otherwise male team an college level.
Perhaps they should also be banned, if they are similarly reinforcing harmful gender stereotypes.
Male-dominated sports are flexible in allowing women. Even in countries like Iraq, women and girls are training to be wrestlers. Women's boxing was included as an event in the 2012 Olympics.
Male-dominated sports have been captured by women and been transformed into a tool to fight gender stereotypes.
Those who are the first women in a male-dominated sport, such as Jackie Mitchell in baseball, act to inspire future generations of women.

Sports such as baseball do not rely on inherently violent or otherwise morally problematic activities. This is why trailblazers can inspire future generations. But there is nothing inspiring about being the first to engage in violent or otherwise immoral acts.
Gender marking, e.g. a different visual representation of women and men, is not present in the fight of female bullfighter Cristina Sanchez.
Mexican bullfighter Karla de los Angeles aims to perform well in order to eradicate sexism in bullfighting.
Female bullfighters often complain about fighting sexism within bullfighting circles, in addition to fighting bulls.
Bullfighting is overly dangerous for participants and spectators.
In various cases, spectators have been seriously injured during bullfights.
In 2015, a bull jumped over a barrier during a bullfight in Peru and injured at least four people.
In 2010, a bull escaped the ring during a bullfight in northern Spain and injured more than 40 spectators.
In 2014, a bull managed to jump over a fence in a bullring in Mexico City and injured at least one person.
In 2006, a bull jumped into the stands of Mexico City’s most famous bullring and injured several spectators.
These instances may be a reason for better safety precautions but not for an outright ban.
Better, stronger barriers could be built to help protect spectators.
Following the Le Mans disaster, car racing underwent substantial reform to stop similar incidents in the future.
After the 1955 Le Mans accident, some sponsors and participants imposed a voluntary ban on themselves, such as Mercedes.
Following the Bradford City fire, sports stadiums in the UK were regulated to prevent future fires or deaths in such incidents.

The Bradford City fire was a fire entirely unrelated to the match or the sport, the issue was simply building standards. Regulating the construction of a building is a simple task, ensuring that spectators are sufficiently fenced off from a panicked, 600-odd-kilo animal is not, at least without removing them so significantly from the "action" that bullfights would be functionally unwatchable live.
It would be roughly as reasonable to claim that the Theatre Royal disaster means that theatre is unsafe, or that the Bethnal Green disaster means that stairs are death-traps.
Fatal accidents in American ice hockey have not resulted in calls for banning the events, merely for better measures to protect spectators from stray pucks.
It is easier to stop a small inanimate object from leaving a playing field than a half-tonne panicked animal.
Professional and non-professional bullfighters suffer severe injuries and sometimes even death.
In 2013, there were at least 47 injuries in 661 bullfights. This amounts to an injury in 7% of the fights.
Many of the injuries are gruesome to watch, as they usually involve someone being stabbed by the bull's horns.
In any reasonable sport, death should not occur except in the rarest of circumstances. Bullfighting makes the news every year for people having died by goring, trampling or some other gruesome means.
Bullfighting carries a considerable risk of serious, life-threatening injuries.
The total number of casualties in 2015, one of the highest in years, was 13 deaths. And since 2000, 74 people have died in bullfighting incidents.
In July 2016, the bullfighter Victor Barrios was the first to die in the ring since 1985. Therefore, the practice went 31 years without a single dead professional bullfighter in Spain.
There is an upper limit on the amount of harm that the government should allow people to expose themselves to in the course of employment or leisure.
Employment can be a coercive factor in decision-making, particularly for the economically vulnerable.
If someone takes a job on account of economic pressures, the state should not let them risk their life in the course of their employment.
Bullfighting schools are relatively expensive. It is unlikely that the economically vulnerable will become bullfighters.
One could attend bullfighting school at a time when they have money to do so, but this does not mean that they will always have the economic freedom to make rational decisions.
Scholarships exist for matador schools.

The risk and danger are an integral form of what makes bullfighting appealing as an art form. This cannot be compared to other forms of employment where risk and danger are an unwelcome side effect. Because this inherent danger cannot be ameliorated, the practice should simply be banned.
Other sports, too, are based on risk and yet face no ban, for example extreme sports such as base jumping.
Individual participants do not necessarily understand the risks. Governments are in a better position to make this assessment and should act accordingly.
Bullfighters go through comprehensive training and are well aware of the sport's dangers.
Being told the dangers does not mean that you understand them, or are in a position to appropriately weigh them.
Bullfighting degrades the people that participate as well as the animals that are exploited. No one should be proud of terrorizing and torturing an animal trapped in a ring.
Taking away the right to choose meaningful employment removes individual agency.
Individual agency is not an absolute value. It needs to be weighed against other values such as social utility.
This does not take away the right to choose meaningful employment - there are many other industries people could be meaningfully employed in.
People are free to harm themselves. Self-harm practices are often not banned.
Self-harm practices are a sign of a lack of coping skills and often associated to mental illnesses. Illnesses cannot be prohibited, while bullfighting can.
The government does not restrict the right of people to work in far more common, yet dangerous industries.
For example, poultry workers are exposed to a diverse set of dangers.
In the United States, 151 people died from meat and poultry jobs between 2004-2013, averaging 15 deaths per year.

This is not an accurate comparison, given the number of people employed as workers in each industry. There are around 500,000 people employed in the meat and poultry industry in the US alone. In contrast, there are only 661 bullfights each year in Spain.

In addition, those 500,000 meat and poultry workers are mostly working full time, and therefore have significantly more opportunities to be injured than bullfighters who are working in short irregular events.
Human Rights Watch has called meatpacking "the most dangerous factory job in America".
In other branches of the meat industry, safety standards are very high and the percentage of workers injured each year in the US has decreased from 20% in the late '90s to 6% in 2012.
Bull fighting is cruel, not just to the bull, but also to men expected to risk themselves for other people's entertainment.
There is concern that exposure to bullfighting can significantly harm a child's mental health and brain development.
In Mexico, the practice of novillada uses extremely young calves in the ring.
Being a child matador helps develop high levels of discipline.

Participation in and spectacting of bullfighting is not mandatory. If people want to risk life and limb doing something dangerous, fully informed, then a government has no special business stopping them from doing so.

The aggression catharsis hypothesis suggests that bullfights are useful to collectively free ourselves of negative and aggressive feelings, which are inherent to human nature, thereby ensuring people do not take out their aggression on others.
Negative and aggressive feelings are not inherent to humans but socially and culturally produced.

It is irrational to think that enacting violence against someone frees us of that very violence. Just as meditation and acts of peace stimulate a peaceful state of mind. Violence and hurting others begets violence and the capacity and tendency to hurt others. Catharsis and Aggression in Social Psychology.
Several other sports satisfy this need already, such wrestling, rodeo or ice-hockey.
No animals may be killed for audience satisfaction at a rodeo, but animal cruelty is still a big part of it.
Rodeos are also cruel and should also be banned by the logic of the topic.

Bullfighters, and by extension, bullfighting enthusiasts, are uncommonly sensation-seeking individuals. The thrill comes from the extreme nature of the sport. It is unlikely that a rodeo will satisfy these desires.
There are plenty of sports that involve a risk to participant's lives, and high-adrenaline - rodeo-riding is actually a very good example.

The catharsis hypothesis - that aggressive behavior reduces anger and aggression - has been consistently proven wrong; aggressive behavior rather leads to more aggressive thoughts and behavior (Bushman et al., p. 368, 374).
If aggression towards animals is precieved as normal, the step to aggression against other humans is smaller as well.
Children who were shown videos of bullfighting were seen to have higher levels of aggression.
The act of collective scapegoating the bull in this way does not in and of itself justify a practice.
The public celebration of cruelty, violence and death normalises these things in society.

Watching an animal suffering for enjoyment will lessen peoples capacity to empathy. Being repeatedly exposed to pain and suffering of a living being while people around them cheer may reaffirm that animals are to be treated as objects and do not deserve empathy. They may then be less likely to react when faced with suffering and pain of other living beings outside of the arena.
Children are especially vulnerable to normalisation of aggression when exposed to violence at bullfights.
Humans learn by imitation. Exposition to such violence as something "joyful" (especially at young age) may likely lead to more violence and the justification of it.
Children who have been largely exposed to TV violence are generally more inclined to assume aggressive and dominant behaviours.

The screening of early evening bullfights by Portugal’s state owned TV station was prohibited by a court verdict. The court found that televised bullfights can have negative impacts on minors and on the development of their personality.
As children are exposed to violence they negatively internalize the behavior (p. 33).
Adults who attended bullfighting as minors have memories that persist after many years, and are often associated with negative feelings and trauma.
Children who have been exposed to violence show much higher levels of aggression than those who have had no exposure (Gentile, p.33-34).

The violence children see in bullfighting can impact their compassion towards other beings, even humans and make them less compassionate and less kind. We should try to have more compassion in the world, not less.
In some regions of Spain, children under 14 years of age have to be accompanied by an adult because of the cruelty of the events (Brandes, p. 788).

Problems associated with children's exposure to violence include disruption of typical developmental trajectories through psychobiological effects, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), cognitive consequences, and peer problems.
Bullfighting can be televised during hours when children are less likely to watch, e.g. after 10pm.
The Spanish state-owned TVE stopped the live coverage of bullfights between 6am and 10pm, because it considered it not suitable for children.
This decision was revoked by Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy in 2012.
This regulation was overturned for Spanish bullfights, allowing them to be aired during prime time television.
Children can simply watch bullfighting online, as in this channel.
This does not keep children from attending the actual bullfights or looking at the television.
A lot of countries put age limits on bullfighting arenas, so small children are not bullfighting spectators. In Ecuador the minimum age is 16, in Venezuela 18 and in Spain it varies from 12 to 16.

In Spain, the relevant laws vary from place to place and in a lot of cases there are no restrictions. Even when they exist, they are rarely enforced and only recently have some organisers been fined for letting children in the arenas.
Children are exposed to far more violence in video games and films, and for much longer periods of time.
The violence portrayed in the media is fictional and not real.

Of only 300 murders that year in Spain, the only European country with bullfighting, only 60 of those involved minors as perpetrators in 2016. Germany, only one year later, reported a very similar number of 53, despite no possibility of its youth being exposed to bullfighting . el correo statista

When people see these activities applauded by audiences, they internalise the idea that these activities are accepted by society in general. This damages the important social norms against violence and cruelty in general.

Continued depiction of cruelty to animals makes for a society insensitive to the suffering of any sentient being and contributes to the immorality witnessed every day via social media, television and 24/7 news sources.

There is something sad when you see people enjoying the torture an death of an animal. Even if its prettied up with music, sun, sangria, beautiful colors and a pasodoble played by the band. To kill an animal for pleasure, art or joy makes us less humans.
While this is a common claim in commentary on violent activities, there is a lack of research to back up the claim that such a link exists.
Spain has relatively low murder rates: clearly the presence of bullfighting alone is not a good indicator of violent impulses in a society. elmundo
The Cambridge Declaration of Conscience declares animals as sentient, so such the relief from aggression applies to nonhuman animals as well.
Watching and participating in bullfights harms the emotional and mental well-being of children.

The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child expressed its concern about the physical and mental well-being of children involved in the training, as well as the mental and emotional well-being of children who watch bullfights. It considered the eventual prohibition of the participation of children in bullfighting. (UNCRC, p. 10)
As rational human beings, we can find other ways to free ourselves of negative feelings (e.g. art therapy), which avoid the pain of animals.
Injuries and deaths are not an integral part of bullfighting and its competitiveness, but unfortunate accidents, similar to injuries in any other sport.
Around the world, more than 100 soccer players have died while playing or shortly after since 1984. Therefore, applying the same logic, soccer should equally be banned.
These numbers are misleading: soccer matches are vastly more numerous and frequent than bullfighting.
These cases are very infrequent in bullfights.
No sport ends with the deliberate death of one unwilling participant.
Bullfighting is cruel.
It's unethical to harm animals for the sake of human entertainment.
In bullfighting, torture is spectacularized, which adds to the cruelty.
Bullfighting is exceptionally barbaric as the bulls are not even killed for their food but solely out of pleasure.
The meat of bulls that were killed in bullfights is used for human consumption.
Bulls will be killed regardless of whether their meat is eaten or not.
Bullfighting represents a form of zoosadism, where humans inflict harm on animals for amusement.
Inflicting pain to undefended beings just for amusement is not morally acceptable.
The bull has the option of defending itself. The proof is the men who died in duel.

Bullfighting it's also an historical and mythical tradition that has to do with the hero concept and it's hability for facing death. It's a ritual that enlarges our idea of life and death. There's a culture behind the whole thing.

Just because something is a tradition, doesn't mean that this should be morally accepted. Bacha bazi in Afghanistan is also an old tradition but does it mean forcing children to provide sexual services should be accepted.
Create suffering to an animal just for entertainment goes against the human values that distinguish us as human beings.
Legally determining what constitutes spectacularization of violence is a slippery slope that has the potential to impede on the freedom of speech and expression.

Slippery slopes of this kind only occur when lawmakers and the public fail to draw - and stick to - moral lines and principles. There is no reason to believe that they would be so bad at it in this case as to "slide" all the way from protecting animals to censoring speech.

Spectacularization of violence has nothing to do with freedom of speech and expression. The first is about physical damage to someone and torture, while the other is a universal recognized human right.

Even when there is a "slippery slope," it does not necessarily follow that we cannot see some things as cases of unwarranted spectacularization.  This is why most countries ban dog fighting, for example.
The most exciting part of bullfighting is not the torturing or killing of the bull, but rather the toying with it and the bullfighters doing daredevil stunts with the bull.
In Portuguese-style bullfighting, the bull is not killed in the arena and oftentimes survives the fight.

Despite their name, Portuguese "bloodless bullfights" are anything but bloodless. Even if the bull is not killed in the ring, it is dragged out and left bleeding to await his slaughter, hours or even days later.

Some areas of Spain have forms of bullfighting where the bulls aren't killed in front of an audience, such as in Amposta (in Catalonia) where a local tradition consists of attaching flaming torches to bulls' horns in a makeshift arena.

Bulls are naturally fairly sedentary, and are neither inclined towards nor suited to sustained physical exertion of the kind this is used to cause. This alone is cruel, as it causes metabolic acidosis, which causes muscle damage, and various other stress-related suffering.
The activity scares the bulls. Even if it doesn't kill them, it is still cruel.
Things that scare humans are not banned. So it should not be the case for bulls.

Therefore, the bull should not be harmed. The sport as a test of bravery and skill should consist of whether an unarmed brave human can perform the same stunts with a physically healthy and unharmed bull.
A sport is not defined merely by its most exciting part but by the totality of activities. These include the maiming and killing of the bulls.

Bullfighting professionals and fans have rejected the suggestion of adopting the Portuguese-style of bullfighting (where the bull is not killed) in Spain, arguing that killing the bull is an integral part of the Spanish tradition.
In India or in Portugal, the bull is not killed or maimed in any way. Yet the game is still fun.
To the organizers and participants (except the bull, who cannot claim otherwise for itself), this practice is not a "spectacularization of torture". That is a relative term.
The audience response to bullfightingdepends on the individual’s own taste, social and educational background, and their tolerance of other cultures.
People generally do not like to admit that the activity they are participating in is cruel. Fans and participants are hardly impartial assessors of the activity.
Many spectators want to leave the bullring before the end of the fight because they can't stand the show, even if this is often very difficult to do. (Hosseinpour, p.37)
The vast majority of tourists are appalled by what happens at a bullfight and leave after they see what happens to the first bull (p. 15).
Word-of-mouth reviews from appalled tourists will, over time, degrade the pool of foreigners interested in seeing a bullfight.
After witnessing the cruelty involved, 90% of tourists who attend a fight will never return to watch another.
Tourists are almost by definition one-time or at the very least extremely infrequent visitors.
Even if they leave after the first match, tourists have already paid for the experience. Thus, it is still an economic boost to regions where bullfighting is practiced.
Generally speaking, relying on dissatisfied customers is not a good economic model.
This is only one account and does not represent a general occurrence.
As a culture, we have no problem with the spectacularization of torture and death. See, for example, violence in Hollywood blockbusters.
Hollywood blockbusters, while often depicting imagined violence, do not inflict real violence, torture, or death on those involved in their production.
This thread debates the spectacularization of violence. Considered merely as a spectacle, it is irrelevant whether or not the violence is real or simulated.
No matter the form of violence, witnessing too much of it will have a desensitizing effect.
This commits the naturalistic fallacy. Just because we do enjoy the spectacle of violence does not mean we should.
Bullfighting bulls that are deemed not fierce enough are castrated, so that only the best and strongest genes are passed on. This is a cruel practice.

Some young bulls are also castrated to make them less fierce for the sole purpose of being used in bullfighters' training. Other types of bulls are also castrated and used to move herds along in bull-runs.
When performed correctly and with anaesthetic, castration is a humane treatment compared to what other economically nonviable male animals have to endure, such as chick culling.
Castration is one of the standard tools used in the domestication of animals.
Cats and dogs are often castrated. This is not a cruel practice.

There is a sharp difference between the castration of pets such as cats and dogs, generally done under anaesthetic and with pain management, and the castration of livestock such as cattle, sheep and pigs, which is usually done without anaesthetic.
The fact that bulls are - like human beings - sentient creatures creates moral responsibilities towards them. These responsibilities are not compatible with the practice of bullfighting.
Animals deserve the same treatment as human beings.

There is no difference emotionally between a bull a dog or a human were all capable of feeling pain and sadness so why not promote love and happiness And give all equal chance to live the happy life they choose for themselves
Animals are in the world as living beings in their own right. Nothing gives us the right to cause unnecessary suffering for entertainment.

Given the overwhelming power of human civilization to wipe out other species combined with the fact that decreasing biodiversity is universally harmful, we (humans) have a responsibility to care for other species on Earth.

Bullfighting reinforces the idea that animals are products, and that it is okay to use and abuse them for our pleasure, in this case entertainment. This baseless discrimination and objectification in and of itself is morally wrong.
Anything which is not beneficial to either party should be banned. All living beings have the right to live their life with dignity and respect.

Philosopher Peter Singer explains how the only morally consistent principle of equality lies in the idea of equal consideration of interests. If this is accepted, there is no morally justifiable reason to treat animal life as less valuable than humans.

If we measure the value of interests on the idea that our species is superior to other animals purely because of physical features that set us apart, we opt in to what Singer calls "speciesism," the same system of belief that racists adhere to.

Bullfighting perpetuates the belief that humans have the right to deal with an animal as an object and in a damaging way. Such an attitude is socially harmful because it can spread to weaker people or even children.

If we measure the meaning of interests such as pain and happiness of sentient beings on the basis of how intelligent the being is, then logically we should consider the interests of stupid people as less valid.

The capacity animals have for suffering and enjoyment is no different from that of humans. Animals' inability to express their interests in order to achieve happiness and avoid suffering does not make those interests any less valid.
We are relieved of the responsibility to give animals the same rights as humans because humans consciously agree to act civilly while animals do not.

We give humans rights because we expect them to respect the rights of other individuals and the laws that lay the foundation for a civilized society. Animals are unable to comprehend the rules of society and the impact of their actions and so we cannot expect that they will respect others. This means that animals cannot be held accountable for their actions, unlike humans.
When humans do not abide by their responsibility to act civilly and follow laws, we strip them of their rights through means such as imprisonment, in order for civilized society to function.

People restrict themselves because they understand the impact of their own actions. Because animals cannot understand the meaning of the harm caused nor the consequences of committing an act such as murder or assault, their actions are not restricted by that knowledge.

There are many instances where we give the right to protection from needless suffering to animals. This is because we recognize that it is immoral to cause unnecessary suffering to creatures regardless of whether or not we expect a creature to act civilly.
In general, the bullfighting audience enjoys violence against the bull but not against the bullfighter; this is not moral.

During bullfights, when the bull is injured and bleeding, the audience seems insensitive and entertained. However, in the event that the bull attacks the bullfighter, the public exhibits horror and fear.
Dead bullfighters are celebrated and remembered, such as the bullfighter Manolete who was commemorated with a movie.
Animals do not act morally towards humans, a parasitic worm would feed from a human being as a human would feed on beef. There is no reason to threat animals nicer then they treat us.
A human life is worth more than the life of an animal.
A society where the life of an animal was worth as much as the life of a human would be doomed to fail.
Humans, being self-aware, have a greater capacity to suffer than most animals, which gives them greater moral value.
Humans have better skills and capabilities, thus their lives are worth more.
Humans are the kings of the animal kingdom, they have mastered and beaten all other animals, using weapons, traps and intellect and are thus worth more than all the other animals.
Humanity has created culture, art and science.
It is not clear why skill in tasks that humans value should determine the worth of a life.
Human life has a higher value because humans need and depend on each other, socially and economically.

In classical Greek philosophy, humans are described as social or political animals, with an innate propensity to develop more complex communities the size of a city or town, with a division of labor and law-making. Humans need these communities to develop their full potential.

Humans, as members of the same species, can identify with each other, feel what it is like to be in the situation of the other individual and thus develop a stronger feeling of compassion and sympathy than with animals.

Humans, through history, have consistently subjugated and killed other groups of humans by constructing them as "inferior" and "other" based on random ideas, and often for personal gain. Enslaved people have often been valued less than animals.
Appreciation and commendation, which is very important to humans' self-perception, can only be given by other humans.
Animals may not be able to verbalize commendation, but they are clearly capable of giving affection and unconditional regard. Both of these help with self-perception and well-being.
Indeed, animals are used in therapy, to do this in ways that humans are not capable of.
The dominating form of economic organization is division of labor. Everyone is a specialist and highly depends on other individuals' skills and products.
Animals are also responsible for important social tasks, e.g. guide dogs or therapy animals. Humans depend on animals for these functions.
This may make us appreciate other humans more than we do animals, but does not mean that animal lives do not have value - to themselves, to other animals, and to the world.
Because of their biological characteristics, a human is worth more than an animal.
Humans and animals are both just biomass. The self-perception of humans does not make for a good objective measurement.

Measuring the value of a creature on earth by taking into account its contribution to the condition of the biological system, the animal's life is more valuable, as it does not damage the ecological balance.
Religious teachings emphasize the higher value of human life.
Humans are the counterpart of god, provided with an immortal soul. Animals are, according to the Bible, subjects to humankind.
It is not clear why religious teachings should be treated as definitive here. Most modern societies are secular, and seek to have a better justification for their laws than mere religious texts.
The religious concept of reincarnation suggests that an animal could become a human in another life (and vice versa), so their relative worth is subjective.
Generally speaking, in all societies, humans treat a human's life as more important than that of an animal.
Taking the life of an animal has fewer consequences than taking the life of a human.
Humans accept most livestock being treated in an abominable fashion, before being slaughtered.
Humans enjoy basic rights and liberties as guaranteed by a wide range of domestic and international institutions. Animals do not have these kinds of rights and protections.
It is only in war situations that a human life is considered expendable for a cause. Otherwise the utmost is done to protect human members of society.
Firemen save humans first. Even after they have saved any humans, they will only save animals if they can do so without risk.
How humans value lives does not necessarily indicate how humans should value lives.

At the very least, this is not universally true. International and sustained outrage over the shooting - and death - of a gorilla whose actions were threatening the safety of a toddler who had fallen into his enclosure indicates that in some cases, humans will actually value animal lives over those of other humans.
Radical Hindu groups in India have been criticized for assigning more value to cows than to women and untouchables.
Most people who donate to wildlife organisations do not treat human lives as being more important than lives of animals.
Pets in the developed world often have more comfortable and secure lives than humans living in other places around the world.

When faced with a hypothetical situation in which they could save only their pet or a foreign tourist from being hit by a bus, 40% of study participants chose their pet. This shows that almost every second person considers the life of an animal (their pet) more valuable than a human life.

The experiment represents individual reactions of biased pet owners and not general societal rules. If the participants had been asked about a categorical imperative for how society should handle situations like this, their answers would have been different.
If people saved their pet rather than the human, then they would be prosecuted for failure to render assistance to a person in danger and go to prison.
Actually, the vast majority of legal systems impose no legal duty to act to save the life of a stranger.
Surveys on complex moral thought experiments are interesting but unreliable, as people themselves have a very hard time predicting how they would react.
Pet lovers care about their pets because they have a special relationship with them, not because of their pets' status of being animals. Thus, the pets are deserving of receiving this much love.

It is safe to assume that, given the situation where the love for the human would equal the love for the pet, choosing the pet over the human (whom that person had a similar bond with) in a life or death situation, would be considered to be wrong and probably sick.
However the percentage decreases drastically to 2% if the human in the hypothetical situation is a friend or family member.
If an alien species found humans and saw us as animals with lives of less value than theirs, it would still be unfair for us to die for their entertainment.
Even if this is true, it does not prove that animal lives should be treated with no regard, merely less.

This is an invalid comparison, as a policy banning bullfighting would not put human lives at stake. Thus, this is not a trade-off between human life and animal life. The correct comparison should be whether or not human entertainment is worth more than the life of an animal.

As the scientific knowledge on sentience continues to grow and we understand more and more about the impact humans have on animals, it becomes increasingly unethical and illogical to continue to cause animals harm.
Many studies have shown that animals possess characteristics associated with sentience.

There is evidence that cows specifically have relatively high sentience. There is evidence that they experience prolonged emotional reactions to physical and emotional trauma, and that they can be trained to navigate mazes.
Neuroscience proves animals experience a wide range of emotions.

The judgement of pigs - like that of humans - is shaped by both their basic personality traits and their mood. This demonstrates that understanding and applying sentience to animals may have all sorts of complications.

During the 18th century and the age of the Enlightenment we saw great changes in how animals were viewed, with a number of philosophers discussing the ability of animals to suffer (sentience).

Jeremy Bentham, a central figure in the late English Enlightenment, considered the suffering of animals to be a matter of ethical concern for utilitarian thinking, famously asking “The question is not, Can they reason? nor Can they talk? but Can they suffer?”
The acceptance of harm to animals by society has decreased over time. This is reflected in the measures that have been taken to protect animal welfare all over the world.
The Australian Livestock and Rural Transporters Association (ALRTA) has outlined the policies its members should adhere to in its National Animal Welfare Policy.
Nations seek to protect animals from cruelty through legislation.

New Zealand, England and Wales, Scotland, and Australia are examples of an growing number of legal jurisdictions around the world who have updated their animal welfare legislation to incorporate positive duties of care based on the principles of the Five Freedoms.
There are a handful of animal protection laws, such as those that prohibit dog and cockfighting, that also deal with things considered illegal sports.
Acknowledgement of animals as ‘sentient’ was introduced to New Zealand’s Animal Welfare Act 1999 in August 2015.
Not all nations have animal welfare legislation.
Some businesses support animal welfare above financial incentives.
Two major airlines have stopped transporting laboratory animals from mainland Spain to the Canary Islands, an archipelago in the Atlantic Ocean.
Many organizations have spoken out against bullfighting.

Bullfighting does not currently receive substantial subsidies. Despite the decision, €130 million will still be devoted to bull breeders, as farming and cattle subsidies are given on the basis of land surface, not the specific activity that takes place in it.
In April 2004, Barcelona City Council declared its ‘anti-bullfight’ stance.
