The historical experience of bullfighting has lent itself to become a source of modern day identity.
Early 20th century Spanish literature traces bullfighting as an age-old tradition that is peculiar to 'Spain' (p. 8).
Bullfighting allows people to reconnect to a traditional and great Spain and therefore is a source of identity.
Bullfighting deepens cultural bonds within the Spanish-speaking world, as it is commonly practised in Spain, Mexico and Colombia.
Parts of the Spanish pro-bullfighting lobby are working to have it listed it on Spain's intangible heritage list with UNESCO.

Bullfighting was necessary for the creation of Spain once the reconquista was successful, as it provided a set of common traditions that could be practiced by the inhabitants of the Iberian Peninsula.
It was only in the late 19th and 20th centuries that bullfighting experienced a boost.

Despite being contested in other periods, bullfighting experienced a boost during Franco’s dictatorial regime: it had the backing of the government and those who opposed it could not express their opinions (Larene Read, p.14).
During Franco’s dictatorship, while bullfighting was encouraged and imposed as a national symbol, other practices were diminished or prohibited.
Many Spaniards do not see  bullfighting as a symbol of pride, but rather as an imposed and continual denial of Spain’s plurinationality.
For many Catalans, bullfighting is associated with general Francisco Franco, who during his regime declared bullfighting to be a Spanish national celebration.

Nation building is always a modern process. Nevertheless, it conveys a feeling that roots reach long into the past. The Korean nation, for example, was invented in the late 19th century, but claims to have a linage as far back as 2333 BC.
Spanish bullfighting practices were perceived by Ancient Rome as something distinctly Spanish. This points to its importance before Spain formed as a distinct nation.

The validity of bullfighting has been contested several times in Spain's history. Enlightenment intellectuals regarded it as barbaric and considered it a spectacle to disenfranchise the masses from wider political issues. Thus the expression, mimicking Latin, “bread and bulls”.
Many in Spain do contest the practice of bullfighting - especially the Catalans, those who identify with a modern Europe and animal rights activists.
The case of Cuba - where bullfighting has been replaced by baseball as a cultural touchstone - illustrates both the cultural power that this sport has and how it can be changed.
Bullfighting is an important part of culture in Spain.
Bullfighting is important to the conservative elements of Spanish society, who value the sport's traditional roots.
In Spain, it is supported by the Monarchy as well as by right-wing political parties.

The notion of publicly stabbing cattle with knives and spears for entertainment is totally barbaric and such a stain on Spain's character, morality and compassion. Killing an animal slowly and ritually with knives and spears is a sadistic form of torture and totally unacceptable.
Bullfighting is strongly supported by tourism, suggesting that it is more important to people outside of Spain than locals.
Bullfighting is not popular in all of Spain. Some provinces have discouraged or banned the practice.
Catalonia banned bullfighting in 2010.
The national government overturned this decision in 2016, declaring it unconstitutional as decisions over Spanish heritage had to be taken by the central government.
According to a government poll, 65% of the Spanish population have an interest of between 0 and 2 out of 10 in bullfighting.
Spanish law still defines bullfights as part of Spain's cultural heritage. Regional bans have been overridden by the Spanish Constitutional Court on this basis.
Isabel Díaz Ayuso, Madrid's conservative mayor, is more popular than ever. She is vocally pro-bullfighting.
Human rights come before animals. In this case, the right for cultural expression.
The right to participate in cultural life is considered imperative to create a dialogue around diversity, safeguarding heritage, strengthening creative industries, and encouraging cultural pluralism
Prohibiting bullfighting can lead some to defend their rights, leading to public unrest.

Differences of opinions, contestations and confrontations are normal (and healthy) part of social interaction (very much like we are doing by using this Kialo site). Reason why, when they get out of hand, an authority is supposed to be there to support, and keep the peace.
When there's social unrest and chaos, this is a sign of something that is potentially a threat to society. In this case, ruling body or authorities need to take charge for the welfare of society.
Campaigns against bullfighting already target individuals, such as Frank Evans.
Unfair to the slaughtered animals: *they* do not get a chance to rebel, protest, defend or fight for *their* rights. Their voice, opinion or needs are disregarded.
Individual transgressions cannot be a good guide for state policy because they are isolated instances.
Humans enjoy basic rights and liberties on different levels, from UN Declaration of Human Rights to national constitutions. Animals do not have these kinds of rights and protections.
Legal trends indicate that animals have rights.
The Lisbon Treaty of the EU introduced the recognition that animals are sentient beings and deserve welfare.
In 2008, a committee of Spain's national legislature became the first to vote for a resolution to extend limited rights to non-human primates.
At best this indicates that some basic rights exist for some animals. It does not prove that animal rights exist in general.

The right not to suffer and be tortured is of much more importance than the right to preserve a culture. Therefore, it is not sufficient that we assume human rights are more important than animal rights, we would have to assume that animal rights are of a much smaller importance to put something like culture before physical suffering. Besides, the cruelty involved in Bullfighting seems to strenghten socially pervasive cultural traits instead of any desirable ones.
Cultural practices, discourses and material expressions surrounding bullfighting give social meaning to societies.

Jallikattu in Tamil Nadu, India is a 5,000-year-old tradition that is conducted during a harvest festival and is read by some as a "cultural resistance to an urban modernity that tends to marginalise rural and agrarian values".
Bullfighting is so cruel that the Indian Supreme Court banned it.
The Indian federal government issued a six month executive order that bypasses the Supreme Court and temporarily clears the way for bullfighting events to resume in Tamil Nadu.
Traditions ought not to be beyond critique.

The importance of bullfighting in Spain can be seen in linguistics: 42 idioms come from bullfighting (Boers and Lindstromberg, p. 365) and they are often used by speakers, even without knowing their origin.
In Spain, the bull is viewed with respect and considered a symbol of beauty in the bullfighting community.
The Osborne bull illustrates the importance of the bull in Spanish culture.
In 1997, the Spanish Supreme Court ruled that the "bullboard" has become an intrinsic part of Spanish identity landscape.
When a Spanish court ordered the Osborne bullboards removed, there was major public outcry by those who feared a loss of identity (Brandes, p. 782).

While the Osborne bull is preponderant in Andalusia and the two Castillas, it is non-existent in Catalonia and has only small presence in the Balearic Islands, The Basque Country or Navarra. The sculptures have been vandalised many times by nationalists or animal activists.

In 2017 the Spanish Supreme Court, following a litigation between Osborne and Badtoro, ruled that bullfighting is part of the Spanish heritage, but the bull is not. The Court also stated that the bull is not an official symbol of Spain, even if sometimes it is used as such.

Beauty should not be represented by a violent act that imposes death to a living being. There is a huge difference between a representation and real life, bioethics do not allow violence by a huge amount of reasons, and this is one of those.
Colombia's Supreme Court overruled a ban on bullfighting because it represents a “cultural form of expression.”
In Spain, bullfighting is so integral that the government plans to include it as an optional school subject.
The plan to introduce bullfighting as a subject in school met fierce opposition both within and outside Spain.
Abstract values like social meaning are not more valuable than concrete ones like material suffering.

Fatal practices should be banned regardless of their cultural meaning. They can be preserved in history books, but they are not necessary to embrace a particular culture. For example: Dueling, Self Mummification, Sati, etc. these practices are now banned but their cultures still persist.
Social meaning is created through more cultural practices than bullfighting.

Internationally-known figures like Cervantes, Goya, Gaudí or Picasso - and the cultural practices associated or influenced by them - offer a less controversial contribution to Spanish culture than bullfighting.
Banning bullfighting should be decided by each individual country, a worldwide ban would lack legitimacy and ignore national and regional specificity.
It is definitely hard to "standarize" global laws, specially when the countries participating on that are not diverse and the power (and ideology) lays always on the same ones.

There are about ten countries in the world where bullfighting is practiced. Whether to ban it is a decision for the people of those countries. It is no business of people living in non-bullfighting countries.
A form of Bullfighting is an important part of India's culture.
Bullfighting is part of the cultural identity of some countries, those who are not part of those countries cannot impose their beliefs in other cultures because they are part of the multidiversity.

The question of whose business it is to make the decision to ban bullfighting is not relevant to the question of whether or not bullfighting ought to be banned. If bullfighting ought to be banned, then those who live in countries where it happens ought to campaign to ban it.
Since moral obligations do not stop at national boundaries, cruelty is the business of all moral people regardless of what jurisdiction they live in.
There are many things that should be decided worldwide and have been: banning the use of child soldiers, banning civilian bombing, torture. It isn't always enacted, but it should be agreed worldwide.
Global precepts like the ones written in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) are valid worldwide.

If we truly adopt a moral relativist outlook, then taboos such as murder and pedophilia could be considered valid in cultures that find them acceptable. However, we should be justified in condemning such norms.

From this view point, issues such as climate change risks, among others, would never be tackled and solved. We are becoming a globalized species, and if we wish to continue in this path, we need to decide some things worldwide.
Banning sprays that harm the ozone layer of our planet was a global decision, it could only work if the ban went global.
If nothing should be decided worldwide, human trafficking should not get tackled.
Bullfighting is a form of art.
Bullfighting is an art as well as a form of inspiration for artists and intellectuals such as Orson Welles, Hemingway, Picasso, Dalí, Lorca, among others.
Artists can draw inspiration from other places which don't include torturing living beings.
In 1936, Federico García Lorca described the bullfight as "probably Spain's greatest poetic and life-sustaining wealth (...) the most cultured 'fiesta' anywhere in the world".
In 2010, Spain's capital city Madrid protected bullfighting as an art form.

The Madrid declaration of bullfighting as art form came later, in response to the Catalonian ban on bullfighting. For this reason, it was considered a political act, in order to reaffirm the power of Spanish traditions against Catalan claims.
It has been suggested that bullfighting ranks as its own artistic discipline on par with sculptures and paintings, for example by Ernest Hemingway and Orson Welles.
Orson Welles trained as a bullfighter in his youth, and is therefore hardly an impartial commentator.
Hemingway and Welles lived in a different time.
Art is timeless. We still admire renaissance paintings of Titian, for example.
Artistic standards change all the time. Renaissance artists would hardly have recognised most modern and post-modern art as such.
In 2011, the Spanish Prime Minister José Luis Rodriguez Zapatero officially recognized bullfighting as an "artistic discipline and cultural product".

This declaration divides the Spanish population (Douglass, 1997, p. 3). Many Spaniards identify themselves with a more liberal, modern, service-oriented, artistically avant-garde, culturally innovative, democratically open, internationally respected Spain, which in their opinion does not include bullfighting.

Bullfighting is often associated with conservatism and traditionalism, with right-wing parties in favour (Partido Popular) and left-wing (PSOE, Podemos, IU) and most regional parties (PNV, CIU) against it.
It has been suggested that the movement of the bull expresses majesty and grace.
Assuming this is true, we shouldn't kill them as murder is not graceful.
The bulls are exhibiting classic signs of panic, suffering and distress. These are not majestic or graceful emotions or experiences.
Other brutal sports, like boxing, are not considered an 'art' either.

Compared to other athletes, bullfighters do interact with the audience for the eventual evaluation of their performance (McCornick, p. 4). This is a shared component with art, but not present in boxing.

Boxing has a long and storied history of participants and managers engaging in interaction with the audience to build hype. Cricket has a strong history of "sledging" - insults to shake opponents and engage crowds. Plenty of sports involve various forms of players engaging with the audience - arguably, more so than many forms of art, which are presented without interaction.
Cricket or boxing results are not decided by the spectators but the results of bullfights are.
The concept of art is a personal one. Hence, it cannot be generalised. (By definiton then, people will always disagree on its meaning)
Art, as the superior aesthetic expression of our creative inner selves, cannot include torture and violence.

Bullfighting is a practice with the aim of showing the society that we, as humans, are superior to animals by making them seem weak and inferior. Some people consider bullfighting an art, yet the massacre of animals should not be considered art from any point of view.
Art very often depends on displays of torture.
Just because an activity is considered a form of art does not in itself make it ethical to perform.
When bullfighting is perceived as a core part of national identity (e.g. in Spain) it brands a country's culture as violent and diminishes its international reputation.

Albeit a very traditional and old form of entertainment, bullfighting is not more than that and, from a moral point of view, individuals do not progress morally after watching an animal fight and die following his instincts.

It also unnecessarily divides the country, the supporters and those against it. Although statistics show that only 19% of adults in Spain supported bullfighting, while 58% opposed it. Monarchy, Government (especially when is Right-wing) and many councils mayors (which could be explained by the chieftain-like state in the countryside), also play a role in the supporters side.

International animal-rights activists (working in several countries) work for the abolition of bullfighting, which they see as torture of animals. Their campaigning against this practice throughout the world influences foreigners' opinion of Spain.

Bullfighting represents a maladjusted display of ethnic identity and cultural identity. Large elements of society or societies that display maladjusted practices should have their leaders stopped, as matadors should be stopped, and should reconsider their moral compasses as a collective whole for supporting maladjusted and morally questionable practices.
Some forms of organization just are not the same as others, because of cultural inequality, lower forms of culture must be changed and brought up to the standards of higher forms of culture

Higher society listens to wider cultural and global cultural voices that delegate standards for how living ought to be. If a society is lower and does not comply with higher societies' reasonings it risks being unopened to change.
Mahatma Gandhi asserted that “the greatness of a nation can be judged by the way its animals are treated.”
Laws shouldn't change merely because of one famous person's opinion.
"Bullfighting is part of the culture in Spain" is a very broad (and misguided) generalization. 84% of people from 16 to 24 years old are ashamed to live in a country with bullfighting.
The identification leads to stereotypes and perpetuates myths about Spain with which many people do not identify.

At the 2016 Toro Jubilo near Madrid, journalists were prevented from attending, which shows that organisers are aware their festival could be seen by outsiders as cruel and unethical, and wanted to minimalize bad publicity.
The loss of reputation is a marginal concern, as there are no significant economic consequences.
Such a reputation could seriously damage the tourism industry, which regularly turns over upwards of €50 billion annually.
Bullfighting sometimes attracts foreigners to Spain.
Non-Spanish bullfighters are attracted to Spain and sometimes even change their nationality, as Frank Evans did.
This appears to be a very small handful of people. It is not clear on the evidence available what benefit these handful of exceptions bring to the nation.
Tourists are drawn to bullfights.

Bullrings are largely sustained by tourists who visit out of curiosity and a belief that if they fail to visit this unique part of Spanish culture, their visit to Spain will not be complete (Larene Read, p. 15).
If bullfighting was prohibited – thus, officially not accepted as part of current Spanish culture – there would be no reason for tourists to regard it as a cultural 'must do' in Spain.
Bullfights are not the only reason why tourists visit Spain.
For Barcelona it was particularly easy to ban bullfighting because most tourists come for Gaudí's buildings, the Picasso museum and the Miro Foundation.
Child prostitution in some countries attracts tourists. Or hunting endangered species. Something being lucrative and attractive to tourists does not make it right.
Countries with bullfighting traditions are not judged by those alone; their positive reputation also draws from many of their other rich cultural practices.
Despite these rich cultural practices, stereotypes about Spain being a country defined by flamenco and bullfighting persist.
The international reputation of one country should be improved through education, progress and innovation, not through law imposition and prohibition.
Education can be slow in improving general sensibility. If something is logically demonstrated to be harmful, the government can enhance the progress and the development of a nation through law.
An analogous example would be the ban of CFC with Montreal Protocol, which showed that waiting for the majority to demand less harmful products can be ineffective.

If a nation's culture is cruel and bloodthirsty (the exquisite tortures of the inquisition come to mind, as does the treatment of South American natives by the Spanish), it's good that other nations should know about this. It is a good thing that bullfighting warns other peoples about the Spanish national character.
Culture and history can be preserved by many other ways, without the need to continue doing the bad practices of it
Museums and books are the way to preserve traditions that no longer fit the actual morale and ethics.
Tradition based on torture and exploitation of the innocent has no place in the 21st century. The Spanish culture has many wonderful things to maintain and offer; this one can afford to be forgotten.
Where a tradition or cultural practice constitutes a threat to humans or animals, the government should intervene and prohibit it.
In a modern, advanced world there are alternative ways in which we can celebrate and honor a culture, which emphasize our social growth and progression and do not require suffering.

For example, an alternative could be the formation of a theatrical performance that takes place in the arena, with traditional music and performers portraying the dramatic history, the conflict and the resolution. This would honor and preserve the cultural history without causing harm.

Traditions require help in order to evolve positively - the force of habit does not question whether the habit is still beneficial or applicable: it requires an outside force to do the thinking. Modern Spain is that outside force.
Female genital mutilation (FGM) is also a cultural practice. Governments and institutions all over the world have recognized that it needs to be fully abandoned.
Other violent traditions have been outlawed. This indicates how violence can be a motivation for abolition.

In 2014, Denmark banned halal and kosher slaughter – an essential part of Muslim and Jewish faith – if animals were not stunned before the procedure. The reasoning of the government was that religion is not allowed to harm animal rights.
France struck bullfighting from its list of intangible heritage in face of animal rights campaigners pointing to its cruelty.
The Roman gladiatorial games declined in the early 5th century because their cruelty was inimical to Christian life and salvation.

There is growing evidence that harmful traditional practices - such as the preference for a son in many societies, or early and forced marriage of girls - can be one of the root causes for discrimination and violence against girls. (UNDAW, 1) If states want to enforce their national and international obligations, namely to eliminate all forms of discrimination based on sex, they need to intervene, regulate or prohibit these practices.
It is possible to keep part of the tradition, modifying it in order to avoid injury or death to the animal

Barbaric traditions don't have to be completly abolished, but can easily be transitioned into symbolic variants (sublimation), such as a sport with movements that resemble bullfighting or some folklore event with a virtual bull fight.
Cultural transformation is an organic process that occurs from individual choices and beliefs. It should not be the role of government to dictate culture.

Cultural transformation does not occur from individual choices, but from collective action. Social movements are the main agents of social change (Della Porta & Diani, p. 21) and their actions are meant to influence their rulers' decisions.

"Castells", a Catalan tradition that involves creating human towers, is also dangerous for participants (especially children, who go on top) and spectators, yet the UNESCO classified it as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity.
A 12-year-old girl was killed after falling from a castell in 2006.
The organisations that make "castells" have improved their safety measures in recent years - for instance, by making children wear safety helmets.
Bullfighting has become a subject of political claims, in which cultural traditions are merely used as source of power.
Bullfighting is central to maintaining a Spanish political identity.
Bullfighting is a pawn in the contest between those supporting a centralized and those supporting a regionalized Spain.

Bullfighting has to be seen in the context of a symbolism. Jaume Sala and Àlex Ferreiro came up with the idea for the Catalan donkey car sticker in 2003, as an alternative and satirical reaction to the Spanish bull.
Regional opposition to bullfighting is massive within Spain.
Bullfighting is not central to Catalan culture.
Bullfighting has strong opposition from the administration and political institutions in Catalonia.
45 towns in Catalonia have declared themselves to beanti-bullfighting.
Bullfighting encounters strong opposition from the Catalan cultural environment.
The Catalan cultural movement of the early 20th century, Noucentisme, started to claim that bullfighting, as savage and Spanish, had nothing to do with Catalan identity (Rabaseda & Matas, p.105).
In Catalan nationalism, there is a feeling that to be a good Catalan, one has to reject bullfighting because it is not a Catalan tradition (Tkac, p. 152).
Bullfighting encounters strong opposition from civil society.
81% of the population of Catalonia opposes bullfighting (p. 787).
Over 600,000 petitions were collected in support of a ban on bullfighting in Catalonia.
Fans and members of the Catalan bullfighting federation (FETC) celebrated the overturning of the Catalan bullfighting ban. They expect the Monumental bullfighting arena to host the sport again soon.
Fans are not a useful sample. No-one is claiming that there are no bullfighting fans in Catalonia, simply that they are a small minority.
There are indications that many in Catalonia do appreciate bullfighting.
In Barcelona, the audience cheered and applauded when the most famous bullfighter José Tomás re-debuted. This indicates the pan-Iberian importance of bullfighting (Brandes, p. 788).
There is a bias involved, as those who visit bullfights are already inclined to appreciate the activity.
The re-debut was accompanied by major protests outside the stadium indicating the ambivalence with which bullfighting is received (Brandes, p. 788).
In Galicia there are often protests against the national decision to preserve bullfights, so the support is not nationally shared.
Bullfighting is a pan-Iberian tradition and thus part of political traditions in all regions.
Catalonia does have bullfighting traditions. Some non-professional practices of bullfighting, like correbous, are still enormously popular in the province of Tarragona.
Even though Catalonia's bullfighting events violate animals’ rights, they are considered to be an integral part of Catalan culture (p. 152).
San Sebastian reintroduced bullfighting after progressive parties lost power.
Bullfighting being part of a region's history does not mean that it enjoys support from the populace, or governing administrations.
The legality of bullfighting is contested between the central institutions in Madrid and those in the region of Catalonia, which even introduced a ban on bullfighting.
Catalonia's ban on bullfighting is less about repudiation of bullfighting than it is about asserting regional control.
Some believe that the real motive of the ban was ridding Catalonia of the Castilian culture epitomized by bullfighting, using animal rights as a new weapon in a nationalist battle.
Critics of the ban said it was motivated more by Catalan nationalism and a desire to assure political independence from Madrid than by a genuine desire to outlaw the tradition.

In 2016, Spain's Constitutional Court overturned the Catalonia ban, saying that bullfighting is part of Spanish heritage and therefore any decision on banning it could only be taken by the central government.
In 1991, bullfighting was also banned in the Canary Islands and the Constitutional court did not express any objection. This shows that bullfighting is being used as a weapon in a political battle.
Political actors, such as Iniciativa per Catalunya, are using the bullfighting controversy to press through their demands for more autonomy, making use of the legal system.

The vote on the ban by the Catalan Parliament came in October 2010, after the Spanish Constitutional Court struck down parts of Catalonia's autonomy charter - including the right to call itself a nation - with a referendum in June 2010.
The legality is more a contest between animal right activists and traditionalists rather than between center and periphery.
Support for this claim can be found in the fact that poor people are more opposed to bullfighting (IPSOS, p. 3). Poor people also tend to be more in favor of animal rights.
The sport has an overwhelming support among sections of Spain, particularly in Andalucía and around Madrid.
Only 21% of those living in the Centre and the South of Spain support bullfighting, while the number soars to 53% in the North or East (IPSOS p.2).
58% of those surveyed opposed or strongly opposed bullfighting. Only 19% of them supported or strongly supported it.
To call 53% supporting it in the area with the greatest level of support "overwhelming support" is misleading.
Even in Andalucia, the number of bullfights held per year halved between 2007 and 2010, indicating a collapse in support.
In 2006, only 25% of Spaniards had an interest in the bullfighting spectacle, and those were mostly older people.
Even though the Basque Nationalist Party strives for more regional autonomy, they reintroduced bullfighting once they grabbed power.

Bildu, a left-wing and pro-Independence Basque party, was the one that banned bullfighting, as they considered it no longer central to the festivities. The Basque Nationalist Party (PNV), a conservative party, was just appealing to its more traditional base.
The majority of Spaniards from all regions and age groups oppose using public funds to support bullfighting (IPSOS, p. 22), which indicates they do not view it as critical to national identity.

Rafael Nadal, Pau Gasol, Fernando Alonso and especially the Spanish national soccer team are sources of national pride that generate national identity and unity in a lot less controversial manner and for a bigger majority than bullfighting.
Spain has other unifying features, such as the national soccer team or the monarch.
Spain has relatively weak symbols of unity compared to other states. The Spanish language, for example, is contested by regional language like Catalan.
The economically and socially dominant Thevar caste group in the state of Tamil Nadu considers bullfighting, known as jallikattu, to be a symbol of their caste supremacy.
Dalits, the former untouchables, are generally discriminated against at bullfights. Often they are forced to do unpaid menial labour and have special segregated seats assigned to them.
In Central and South America bullfighting represents colonial culture of the oppressor. The practice is not rooted in the native cultures.
As an integral part of society, culture is always political and therefore used for political reasons.
Since most everything in culture has to do with the distribution of power, this does not show that bullfighting isn't a cultural tradition.
Cultural components change, as cultural transformation is a natural dynamic process.
Interest in bullfighting is declining and so is its cultural significance.
One poll from 2015 claims only 19% of Spanish adults support bullfighting and 58% are against it.

Bullfighting is a very controversial topic, often with a minority being very passionate about maintaining it and forcing the practice on the wider society. Banning or defunding such practices would accelerate the end of such controversy.
Attendance at bullfighting matches is in severe decline. The number of bullfights held in Spain has dropped from 953 to 398 in 2014, according to the Culture Ministry.
Funds allocated for bullfighting in the past are now being spent on other public services.

Traditional bullfighting may only survive with a big enough number of supporters and spectators so it will probably disappear without the need of prohibition due to the competition of digital entertainment.
The local protests in Tamil Nadu or Southern France against bullfighting bans illustrate the sustained interest.
While there is still enough support for such protests to occur, they do not negate an observable decline in interest in the activity.
Cock fighting was a part of the history and culture of many nations but it is banned now in many of these countries (including all states in the US except for one).
Cruel practices that are similar, like bear-baiting, have been banned in the UK and the US, regardless of tradition.
Western (European) culture has undergone rapid changes, such as a democratic transition and the ensuing sexual revolution.
Communication technologies that allow people to gather and organize foster a culture that opposes bullfighting, by helping animal-rights activists network or offering new forms of innovation.
There is an ongoing generational change in opinion. 60% of young Spaniards disapprove of the sport, compared to 34% of those above 55 (Ipsos, p. 2).
With urbanization, culture transforms, which makes bullfighting less significant.

The urban lifestyle has become increasingly stressful. This leaves less time for entertainment like bullfighting, as people are forced to schedule their time and can focus only on their favorite activities.
In reality, people still make time for entertainment. For example, soccer matches in Spain attract several hundred thousand people every weekend.
With urban growth, bullfighting arenas become more valuable for other purposes than bullfighting, like the bullring in Barcelona that was an transformed into a shopping mall.
In Madrid, for example, the Vistalegre bullring was transformed into a multipurpose arena that holds sports, concerts or political conventions.
Traditions change as societies' values change.
Oppressive practices such as casteism, gender injustice, racism that are part of some cultures are challenged according to the evolving sense of justice of the contemporary populace.
Even if culture changes, cultural fix-points often remain, as illustrated by the continuity of religious lactans iconography in old Egypt and the modern Christian world.
This is a fact, but not a justification for preserving culture touchstones that are violent and cruel.
It is not about whether something is justifiable but whether it occurs.
If bullfighting were forbidden, the "Toro Bravo" cattle population would no longer exist and become extinct.
Beef as side-product from bullfighting bulls was called 'the most ecological meat in the world'. This would be lost if bullfighting is prohibited.
Beef from bullfighting cattle is quite rare and so would not have a large ecological impact.
Niche farmers sustain the populations of rare species, such as Highland Cattle.
Highland cattle are particularly well-suited to the Scottish climate, and thrive more successfully there than other breeds. This is a simple matter of self-interest on the part of farmers.

There is a growing interest in bull meat in gourmet cuisine and an increase in demand. Some chefs and experts believe it should be appreciated and preserved regardless of bullfighting. If this trend takes root, some farmers could breed bulls for their meat instead of fighting.

There does not appear to be any particular evidence that the cattle in question have a smaller environmental footprint than other cattle. Indeed, given that they are kept alive past the point at which other cattle would be slaughtered for food, they may indeed be less environmentally friendly.

The argument used to support this seems to be that the land used to rear bulls for bullfighting also acts as nature preserves. There is nothing inherent in the rearing of these particular bulls that ensures this - indeed, establishing actual nature preserves would be far more effective.
In taking in a holistic view of animal-welfare and ecology, the meat from these bulls could be better on account of the happiness levels of the bulls.
Following a court order banning jallikattu, a form of bullfighting in Tamil Nadu, India, some native breeds used for the sport are on the verge of extinction.
The breeds in question were under threat of extinction at least as far back as 2010, long before the ban. Clearly, bullfighting does little to preserve these species.
It is difficult to imagine a whole breed becoming extinct within the year that's passed since the ban on bullfighting in India.

They are breeds, not species. The extinction of a breed is meaningless, If we take a bull from that stock and breed it with a Norman dairy cow, we create a new breed. When that cow dies, that breed is extinct.. nothing lost, and the breed can be recreated at any time.
This was only proclaimed by one bullfighting supporter and lacks credibility.

Aside from the animals, there is the possibility that bull breeders will sell the "dehesa" (open forest used for pasturing the bulls) to property developers, with the consequent loss of natural habitat.
Since most "dehesas" are cataloged as rustic land, and thus protected from construction, it is unlikely that they can be repurposed.
It is not in the interest of any animal population to be bred simply to suffer for the sake of humankind.
If these bulls only exist in captivity to be harmed, it might be better for the species if they were extinct.
Breeding bulls for bullfights causes ecological problems.

The 'toro de lidia' is one of the best candidate for rewilding since they are one of the closest relative to the extinct Aurochs. Selective breeding for anything that isn't to recreate the Aurochs should be ceased to prevent any further genetic harm so as to not hinder the rewilding effort any further.

Based on how valuable the breed is for rewilding purpose, the 'toro de lidia' should definitely be protected until the world finally understand that we don't have the right to selectively breed species or make them go extinct.
Bull populations and breeds can be sustained even though no bullfighting is practiced.
Using controlled breeding or genetic engineering, we can always recreate the "Toro Bravo" characteristics if need be.
These breeds can be protected by the state in large reserves.
"Toro Bravo" bulls are not only used in bullfights but also in the famous Running of the Bulls in Pamplona.

In Pamplona's celebrations, bulls suffer electric shocks to make them run and are harassed by runners in the streets; a stressing environment for animals bred in quiet fields. At the end of the festivities, bulls are killed in the arena anyway. Therefore, if bullfighting is banned, these practices should be banned as well.

If the people who raise Toros Bravos actually cared about them, they would continue to raise them regardless of whether or not there are bullfights. Their claims as to their probable extinction should there not be bullfights, only point to their total lack of regard for the well-being of the very animals they claim to defend.

People who invest and raise 'Toros Bravos' do so to get economic returns. Regardless if they care about the animals or not, their livelihood depends on these animals being necessary due to the existence of bullfights.
"Toro Bravo" is a breed created by humans to be especially aggressive. They are unnatural and have no value outside of bullfighting. We should let the population die out.
"Toro Bravo" do not have any more right to life than any other cattle. Animal rights are premised on sentience, not whether they display characteristics that humans appreciate.
That right applies to individuals, not species. That does not mean we should prevent a species from disappearing, not by this logic.

The "Toro Bravo" cattle population is not its own species; and calling it a "race" would not be accurate either, since it doesn't have substantial physical differences with other bulls. It's just a more violent breed. If their dissapearance is a real concern, they could be mixed in with other cattle until their violent behaviour gets flushed out, while preserving other characteristics.
Humans did not create the breed Toro Bravo, we simple used the process of artificial selection to shape the extant Bos Taurus and created a new taxonomic label.
If we bred aggression, stamina, etc. into the breed we can also breed those characteristics out and select for characteristics that are more conducive to beef, leather or milk production.
Or we can simply find bulls like the breed which already have those characteristics and save a lot of time. Breeding them out would still make the current form become extinct anyway.
Humans created the "Toro Bravo". We are entitled to discontinue the breed (humanely) if need be.

They wouldn't face extinction rather than a decrease in its numbers, given that officially there would be no more "corridas". But, since nowadays their flesh is sold to be processed and eaten after killed in "la plaza", it is probable that the "Toro Bravo" business would continue to serve meat industry alleged "high quality meat" and as breeders.
Being forced into the meat industry would change the eugenic selection they face, their lifespan and their life condition for the worse.
Bullfighting can benefit national economies.
In Spain, there are around 562 bullfighting arenas that are either run by the government or in private hands. If there are no more bullfights, it would lead to a significant financial loss.
When mobile arenas are included it has been suggested that there are up to 1727 arenas.

The end of slavery also led to a financial loss. Proponents of child labour in some countries use the same argument that "it would lead to financial loss." Just because it costs money, doesn't mean it isn't abusive.
These could be repurposed for other sports, or forms of entertainment.
Many publicly-owned ones ? in some cases, listed buildings or protected spaces ? can be transformed into public facilities that the city or town needs.
Many may be suitable for outdoor theatre and concerts, with minimal refurbishments. The Santamaria bullring in Colombia has previously been used for concerts and other cultural events.
Many, like La Malagueta Plaza de Toros in Malaga are already used for such events, so it would simply be a matter of increasing their frequency.
Many may be suitable as stadiums for other sports, with minimal refurbishments.

If it was so easy to repurpose large buildings, Olympic stadiums all over the world would not leave behind white elephants: large buildings that require constant care and maintenance and cannot sustain themselves.

Olympic stadiums are "white elephants," a white elephant is expensive because it cannot be used due to its beauty, not because it economically/physically cannot be used. One wouldn't hold a tennis game in the Taj Mahal, in the same way Olympic stadiums are preserved.

Olympic stadiums are white elephants because they must hold massive once-in-four-years international audiences, which are larger than audiences for any other sporting event in the world. Bullfights do not draw such audiences in the status quo, and so bullrings are more reasonably sized.
Bullfighting merchandise is sold.
Bullfighting merchandise would not exist without bullfighting.
Anti-bullfighting merchandise is also sold.
Merchandise could still be sold to commemorate past culture after an eventual ban.
Moral considerations are generally taken into account when making economic decisions.

Various industries are billion dollar industries. But at the same time, they can be unethical, or dangerous for human health or environment (arms, tobacco, nuclear...). Ethic should be more important than money.
So can slave labour. Benefitting a national economy does not absolve a practice from being inherently cruel, not to mention morally questionable or wrong.
Qatar is building its installations for the World Cup with questionable quasi-slavery practices, which will no doubt benefit its economy in 2022.
Bullfighting is a billion dollar industry.
In Europe, bullfighting is a €2.5 billion ($3.3 billion USD) industry (p. 12).

This is far less money than it sounds. The Spanish tourism sector alone regularly turns over upwards of €50billion annually - investments in various other attractions or industries could easily replace this amount.
Bullfighting generates millions in sales tax in Spain.
Those who argue that bullfights can not be forbidden because of business are putting the importance of a life and money on the same level, and this is immoral.
If animal cruelty is permissible due to its financial benefits in the case of bullfighting, cruelty to any other nonhuman animal is tacitly allowed if it results in profit of a certain level
Many humans feel more compassion and sympathy for the bull than concern about the business side of things, which reflects the essential concern of the debate.
Organisations like the Nonhuman Rights Project are becoming increasingly popular, just as the acknowledgement of the cruelty of bullfighting is being debated.

Banning bullfighting and removing this source of revenue is more immoral than allowing it, as the estimated €3.6 billion a year that Spain's economy would lose could have been used to help many of its citizens.
The revenue from bullfights does not benefit society; only a small group of breeders and star fighters.
Based on the case of Madrid, where only 5% of the loss occurred directly to the government, this €3.6 billion would make up an insignificant 0.07% of Spain's total welfare spending as of 2013.

The figure of €3.6 billion is likely to be exaggerated given that it was the National Association of Bullfighting Organizers that came up with the figure. After all, it has a direct stake in keeping bullfighting alive.
To many in rural Haiti, bullfighting is a necessary means to make a livelihood.

The claim that it is a necessary livelihood is tenuous, given that the money earned seems to come exclusively from betting, which is inherently unreliable and could be replaced with other, less cruel, forms of gambling.
Bullfighting provides jobs.
Bullfighting employs more than 10,000 people across Spain. If it were banned, they all would be without work (p. 12).
Bullfighting does not actually employ as many people as one might expect. While there might be 10,000 people employed, the number of full-time jobs it provides in Spain is not even 400 (p. 12).

A significant portion of those jobs are in raising cattle, managing events or selling food and/or merchandise. All of those employed in these roles could very easily remain in the agriculture, entertainment or goods and services industry in similar or functionally identical roles.
To offset job losses, the government – or the European Union – could offer the newly-unemployed subsidies.
To help breeders move towards other industries, national governments or the EU could offer subsidies, in the same way as Germany and other countries have subsidised renewable energy.
It would be unlikely that the EU would grant any appreciable subsidy to breeders and fighters transitioning out of an industry that had just been so strongly condemned.
The European Commission has directed substantial effort towards reskilling programs and policies.

Given the EU's support for animal welfare, it has an incentive to ensure that the ban on bullfighting goes smoothly, without obvious negative consequences, to ensure that countries remain willing to make such reforms.
A big portion of EU funds are devoted to agriculture. If bullfighting is banned, the EU could help bull breeders to change their sector and not lose their economic means of survival.
EU rural development projects would also help farmers to re-orient their businesses.
Although Spain's economic woes have improved in the last few years, compensating all those involved in bullfighting post-ban would come at a massive cost.
The loss of jobs should not be a sufficient reason to discontinue an unethical practice.
Losing jobs would help Spain create more businesses and be more creative with their tourist attractions.
Tourist may choose to stay away from bullfighting countries because they are against it. So maybe it would be more beneficial financially to ban it.
Recent studies seem to point out that while tourism initially boosted bullfighting in Spain, it is nowadays an "ambivalent tourist attraction, of declining attractiveness".
Some organizations and travel insurers compel tourist to not attend bullfighting or avoid spending money in accommodations, restaurants or shops that promote bullfighting.
Instead of benefiting national economies, bullfighting receives substantial subsidies.

Spanish MPs presented a report in the European Parliament estimating the amount of public money devoted to bullfighting is €571 million. Their conclusion was that bullfighting would be “on the brink of the financial collapse and unable to subsist” without the public subsidies.
This document displays some examples of subsidies granted to tauromachic events between 2009 and 2015 held in Portugal.

In Portugal, public money is granted to support bullfight via both the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Culture. It could be argued that this money should be spent in other areas rather than to support a practice that does not gather a national consensus nor adds a real economical benefit.

From 2009 to 2011, the public broadcaster televised bullfighting, paying €9 million of taxpayers' money for the rights. Tendido Cero, a program (which started in 1986) specialising in bullfighting, costs around a €1 million per year and has a quite small audience.
Public institutions invest in sectors that they deem worthy of preservation, regardless of their audiences. Cinema, for instances, have always been subsidized.
Subsided animal cruelty sends the message to future generations that it is alright to torture a living being for entertainment.

Public money given to bullfighting can be employed for other social needs. For example, a small Spanish town that dedicated €18,000 to bullfighting festivities could instead use them to fund school supplies.
Regional governments in Spain have already begun to shift funds from bullfighting to education - in the case of A Coruña, based in part on the "cruel spectacle" of the sport.

Very often, bullfighting lives only through public investment. While it moves a lot of people and generates a lot of money, it's frequently not economically sustainable. The allocation of public funds to such a controversial sport over other, more constructive cultural practices, would be preferable in the long term.
In India and France, bullfighting is of marginal economic relevance.
The main economic victims of the bullfighting ban in India were regional bull breeders in just one province.
The recent protests to re-legitimize jallikattu in Tamil Nadu were carried out on purely cultural grounds.
Even conspiracy theories that see the bullfighting ban as western attempt to conquer the Indian dairy industry cannot point to widespread economic consequences.
India and France cannot be equated to Spain.
The assumption that a solution designed for one culture will apply to all others is false
Bullfighting is a sport and therefore should be legal.
Bullfight is both sport and art.

Bullfighting occurs naturally. If a man were to encounter a bull alone in a field, the bull would charge and try to kill the man. Man has taken this and created an artistic event that emphasizes valor while giving the spectator a perspective on the tragedy of life. It is theater where the protagonists risk their lives. It should be appreciated more.

Bullfighting is not a natural occurrence but an organized practice. Selective breeding has maintained or augmented the aggression of the bull. Additionally, bulls are aggressive "especially when solitary or unable to escape” and thus a bull typically raised within a herd in an open and natural environment would likely not be that aggressive and would likely escape and not kill anyone.
Research points out that the charging of the bull is not an attack "but as a way to push away the attackers, to avoid the adverse situation".
Natural doesn't automatically mean good. It's a Logical Fallacy
Sport is good for health, so every sporting activity, like bullfighting, should be encouraged.
Bullfighting is actively performed only by a negligibly small share of the population in countries where it is popular. It has therefore no public health benefits.
Bullfighters are considered «artists» or «Masters» by themselves. Bullfighting is in fact originally a ritual in where a man, sacrifice animals in behalf of his god.
Running is healthy. People can run as a sport. Running with the aim of torturing an animal isn't a sport. If we called murder a sport because it may include running, that would not make it right.

An activity being good for the physical health of one who practices it, does not justify that activity being legal or encouraged. If someone runs after someone and kills them, they will not be excused because the act of killing involved running and running is good for their health.
Participating in sport is good for health, but bullfighting is largely a spectator sport, meaning that very few people gain any health benefit from it.
The bullfighter shares the need for intelligence, physical fitness and coordination with most other athletes.
So would a practitioner of human hunting or a thief planing a high-stake heist. The skills alone do not make a sport.
The bioethical and animal right's ideals must prevale before the sports and pleasure of a collective or individual.
Other sports have limits on their violence (p. 12). Bullfighting ends with death.

Some TV episodes have antagonists kidnap humans and hunt them for sport. Sports definition is along the lines of 'competition involving physical exertion and skill.', arguably every theft and murder can be considered a sport and definitely every war.
The bullfighting education organisation Aficionados International itself acknowledges that bullfighting "is not a sport in the first place".
Even if an activity is classified as a sport it does not follow that it should therefore be legal. Other activities classified as sports are also illegal.
Other illegal sports, such as street racing, come with significant liabilities to uninvolved third parties. This is not the case with bullfighting.
Bullfighting comes with significant liabilities to both involved parties. While human participation is voluntary and the liability can therefore be ignored, no such claim can be made about bulls.
Bulls are injured and killed doing an activity which they are forced to do. Had the human been in bull's position, it would be classified as torture and murder. This is a clear case of speciesism.
The bull is not a willing participant, therefore it  be considered a third party.
It cannot be regarded a real sport as the fight lacks fairness, as there is very little chance the bullfighter would be injured before the bull.
If bullfighting was fair, the number of bullfighters and bulls that die in the ring would be equal.

The (Spanish-style) bull fighting system is skewed in favour of the matadors. The World Society for the Protection of Animals estimates that around 250,000 bulls are killed each year in bullfights (Spain, Portugal, France, Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela). And only 52 matadors have been killed in the arena since 1700.
The competition is between bullfighters and not between bulls and bullfighter. Between different bullfighters there is fairness.
The bulls are unwilling participants, to whom fairness is not shown. Regardless of whether there is fairness between other participants, this makes it an unfair activity, and thus unsporting.
When and rarely the bull kills the fighter, the bull is still killed. Bullfighting is never an equal fight. Therefore, it cannot be considered a sport.
Bullfighting is not sport. Sports involve competition between two or more consenting parties and the mediation of a referee.
There are many types of sports which do not require a competition between two consenting parties, e.g. the first ascents of rock walls by extreme climbers.
Rockclimbing and the like still don't involve any non-consenting parties, unlike bullfighting.
Extreme rockclimbers are competing with each other - to scale more challenging rock walls than others do, or to scale them faster.
The animal does not choose to partake in the activity. So one could argue that if you are thrown into a boxing ring without consenting (and get beaten up badly) it's a crime.

In the rare cases that a bull survives a bullfight, it is immediately retired as too dangerous an opponent for future fights, as it will have learned from the experience. The entire activity relies on one participant - the bull - having no experience of the event or understanding of what is taking place, and the other participant having substantial support and training.
Bullfighting is not a common sport, but rather a cruel blood sport involving the killing of animals for human pleasure.

Bullfighting is like any other kind of animal fighting where the animal is forced to fight to the death for entertainment at the painful expense of the animal's life: therefore it is not sport, it is animal cruelty.
Bullfighting is not an ordinary sport, but rather an archaic spectacle that is reminiscent of the gladiator fights in ancient times.
The archaic nature of a custom arguably gives it greater value as a symbol of a people's heritage.

Same could be said of burning witches on a stake, enslaving people, having gladiators fight each other to the death. Just because something was part of a culture in the past, that doesn't make it good.
Killing animals for food is killing for pleasure, too.
If one finds enslaving, killing, dismembering, and eating animals acceptable, it is bizarre to claim to care for their well-being.

We should stop killing high-sentience animals such as mammals. That however does not mean we don't care about them suffering without reason when the suffering involved in their death is negligible in comparison.
In bullfighting, the pleasure is derived from the act of killing. This is not the same in killing animals for food.
